Detailed Description

AES module

- AES implementation for APOXI

AES

AES (Advanced Encryption Standard) is a standard recommended by specs such as DRM for content encryption. It is a block cipher supporting many different block sizes like 128 bits, 256 bits etc.

of the C Implementation

The algorithm / implementation used here is by Dr. Brian Gladman and released as free to be used by proprietary and open source software Web Link : http://fp.gladman.plus.com/AES/index.htm

The directory AddOns\ has the APOXI wrapper and AddOns has the C code from Brian Gladman. For copyright details refer to the header files under Aes

Wrapper

The class AesCrypt offers limited functionality keeping in mind the requirements for OMA DRM v1.0. The following section lists the limitations.

AES

Currently AES supports the following features

  • Decryption only
  • Key Size 128 bit
  • Block Size 128 bit
  • CBC mode

Using voice recognition

To decrypt a buffer encrypted using AES, you need the following

  • A 128 bit key used to encrypt the buffer
  • A 128 bit initialisation vector used for encryption (as the first 128 bits of the encrypted buffer)

AES

To use the APIs, the block numbers are calculated as follows

Incoming buffer: +----+----+----+----.......----+ | | | | | | 0 | 1 | 2 | | | IV | | | | +----+----+----+----.......----+

In the above, since block 0 of the incoming buffer is the IV, it won't be present in the decrypted buffer. And hence block 1 in the incoming buffer is referred as block 0 of the output buffer. And hence the start_block and end_block can have values from 0 to (n-1). And the output buffer will have [end_block - start_block] number of blocks.

Member Function Documentation

INT AesCrypt::DecryptBuffer (  const BYTE *  in,
BYTE *  out,
UINT  buf_len,
PaddingMethod  pad_method,
UINT  start_block = 0,
UINT  end_block = 0
) 
 

Decrypts an AES encrypted buffer (using CBC mode). Actual size of the decrypted buffer will be a maximum of input buffer size minus 16 bytes (the initialisation vector). It might be little lesser depending on the padding mode.

Parameters:
in Input buffer (bytes)
out Output buffer (bytes). The Output buffer is allocated and freed by the caller. The caller must allocate a minimum of buf_len-16 bytes of memory for this operation.
buf_len Input buffer length
pad_method Padding method (enumerator
See also:
PaddingMethod)
Parameters:
start_block Starting block number
end_block Ending block number
Returns:
Size of the decrypted buffer
